articles.headline: At Leisure, or Still at Work
articles.snippet: More older Americans are employed part time after they retire, some because they want to and some because they need to.
articles.abstract: More older Americans are employed part time after they retire, some because they want to and some because they need to.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEPHEN NATHAN’S wife persuaded him to retire at age 62, telling him it was too much — and too risky — for him to continue driving 60 miles each way to and from his job in upstate New York.

articles.headline: In New Health Law, a Bridge to Medicare
articles.snippet: Starting Oct. 1, millions of Americans will be able to buy health plans available through online state marketplaces for coverage that begins in 2014.
articles.abstract: Starting Oct. 1, millions of Americans will be able to buy health plans available through online state marketplaces for coverage that begins in 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE sweeping federal health care law making its major public debut next month was meant for people like Juanita Stonebraker, 63, from Oakland, Md., who retired from her job in a hospital billing office a year and a half ago.

articles.headline: A $250 Million Pledge to a College Evaporates as a Deal Collapses
articles.snippet: Centre College in Danville, Ky., announced in July that it had received a $250 million donation, the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college, but it left out a small detail.
articles.abstract: Centre College in Danville, Ky., announced in July that it had received a $250 million donation, the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college, but it left out a small detail.
articles.lead_paragraph: When tiny Centre College, in Danville, Ky., announced in July that it had received a $250 million donation, the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college, it left out a small detail.

articles.headline: Invasive Tactic in Foreclosures Draws Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Property-management companies are coming under fire for using questionable and possibly illegal tactics in their work for banks.
articles.abstract: Property-management companies are coming under fire for using questionable and possibly illegal tactics in their work for banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barry Tatum returned to his home in Chicago in December to find that his front and back doors had been torn from their hinges, leaving his possessions exposed to the frigid winds that whipped through his neighborhood.

articles.headline: What Might Have Been, and the Fall of Lehman
articles.snippet: Five years ago, the government abandoned Lehman Brothers to its fate. Was that a mistake, or did it help bring the financial crisis under control?
articles.abstract: Five years ago, the government abandoned Lehman Brothers to its fate. Was that a mistake, or did it help bring the financial crisis under control?
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s play a game. It is called “What if … .”

articles.headline: Drug Deaths Threaten Rising Business of Electronic Music Fests
articles.snippet: A string of drug-related deaths at big music festivals has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.
articles.abstract: A string of drug-related deaths at big music festivals has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.
articles.lead_paragraph: The electronic dance music business, propelled by huge festivals featuring star D.J.’s and psychedelic light shows, has grown to an estimated worth of $4.5 billion, a number that is luring both Wall Street investors and mainstream corporate sponsors. Yet a recent string of drug-related deaths has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: Judges Hear Arguments on Rules for Internet
articles.snippet: In a battle over whether the Web should remain open, judges expressed doubt over a requirement that service providers treat all traffic equally.
articles.abstract: In a battle over whether the Web should remain open, judges expressed doubt over a requirement that service providers treat all traffic equally.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a momentous battle over whether the Web should remain free and open, members of a federal appeals court expressed doubt over a government requirement that Internet service providers treat all traffic equally.

articles.headline: Survey Reveals Scant Backing for Syria Strike
articles.snippet: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A broad majority of Americans, exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, are opposed to a military strike on Syria, even though most say they think Syrian forces used chemical weapons against civilians, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: In Missouri, Governor Turns Tax Cut Debate Against G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Gov. Jay Nixon has argued that lower taxes would hurt education and mental health services, and has found support in the face of an override vote.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon has argued that lower taxes would hurt education and mental health services, and has found support in the face of an override vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSHALL, Mo. — As a Democrat facing a State Legislature with veto-proof Republican majorities, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri has not claimed big victories lately. So when he began stumping the state against a deep Republican tax cut that he had vetoed, he might have seemed to be on a political fool’s errand.

articles.headline: The Border Is a Back Door for U.S. Device Searches
articles.snippet: Documents released Monday detail the largely secretive process that lets the government detain an individual at a border crossing and confiscate or copy any electronic devices that person is carrying.
articles.abstract: Documents released Monday detail the largely secretive process that lets the government detain an individual at a border crossing and confiscate or copy any electronic devices that person is carrying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newly released documents reveal how the government uses border crossings to seize and examine travelers’ electronic devices instead of obtaining a search warrant to gain access to the data.

articles.headline: Obama Backs Idea for Syria to Cede Control of Arms
articles.snippet: A Russian plan to have international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons offered an exit strategy for President Obama, who had been reluctant to order a military strike.
articles.abstract: A Russian plan to have international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons offered an exit strategy for President Obama, who had been reluctant to order a military strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday tentatively embraced a Russian diplomatic proposal to avert a United States military strike on Syria by having international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons. The move added new uncertainty to Mr. Obama’s push to win support among allies, the American public and members of Congress for an attack.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Michael R. Gordon and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Luxury Brands Face Hazards When Testing Lower Costs
articles.snippet: The addition of a cheaper iPhone could help Apple sell tens of millions more phones, but it could also diminish its reputation as a premium brand.
articles.abstract: The addition of a cheaper iPhone could help Apple sell tens of millions more phones, but it could also diminish its reputation as a premium brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For upscale brands, there is a fine line between “cheaper” and “cheap.” And for Apple, the premium electronics maker, the key is to avoid crossing it.

articles.headline: Obama Delays Syria Strike to Focus on a Russian Plan
articles.snippet: President Obama said he would pursue a “diplomatic path” on the Syria crisis even while making the moral case for punishing the country for its deadly use of chemical weapons.
articles.abstract: President Obama said he would pursue a “diplomatic path” on the Syria crisis even while making the moral case for punishing the country for its deadly use of chemical weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing implacable opposition to a strike against Syria in Congress and throughout the country, said Tuesday that he would hold off on military action for now and pursue a Russian proposal for international monitors to take over and destroy Syria’s arsenal of chemical weapons.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Machines Made to Know You, by Touch, Voice, Even by Heart
articles.snippet: How can Web sites, along with smartphones, refrigerators and television sets, verify your identity? Researchers and entrepreneurs are proposing new tools to leave passwords in the dustbin of history.
articles.abstract: How can Web sites, along with smartphones, refrigerators and television sets, verify your identity? Researchers and entrepreneurs are proposing new tools to leave passwords in the dustbin of history.
articles.lead_paragraph: How does a machine verify the identity of a human being? Irises, heartbeats, fingertips and voices, for starters.
